fields.summary: S3 IAM ARN wildcard causes ACL issues for bucket objects

comments.body:
When doing further testing with two different users with the two different policies above, the following behavior can be seen:

*user02*
* user02 policy
{code}
$ euare-userlistpolicies --as-account account1 -u user02 -v
s3-all
{
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Sid": "Stmt1361565586161",
      "Action": "s3:*",
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::*"
    }
  ]
}

IsTruncated: false
{code}

* s3cmd get 
{code}
$ ./s3cmd/s3cmd --config=.s3cfg-account1-user02 get s3://sometest/test.sh test-user02.sh
s3://sometest/test.sh -> test-user02.sh  [1 of 1]
ERROR: S3 error: 403 (Forbidden):
{code}

* Error in cloud-output.log:

sosreport from CLC, Walrus machine with EXTREME logging.

[~hspencer], [~dshekhawat] 
I believe that what you are seeing is actually the correct behavior according to AWS docs. 
"Buckets" and "Objects in buckets" are two different resource types with different associated actions, so resource arns must be defined for both.
see http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingIAMPolicies.html#S3_ARN_Format
I would like to close this as not a bug.

Code Review Request : EUCA-7340 S3 IAM ARN wildcard causes ACL issues for bucket objects	

branch : dev/mmunn1/EUCA-7340

diff :  git show --color 47392dad891da8e78f28d870f69533386b4c6439

Summary: The following s3 policy behaves differently on Eucalyptus and AWS
{code}
{
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Sid": "Stmt1361565586161",
      "Action": "s3:*",
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::*"
    }
  ]
}
{code}
On AWS the above policy allows "all actions" on "all buckets" and "all Objects".
On Eucalyptus the above policy allows "all actions" on "all buckets" but
not on "all objects".

Solution: modify the Ern.parse() to return "*" instead of "bucket" in the special
case of "arn:aws:s3:::*" where no object is defined. This fix will address this issue
only. There seems to be other differences in the way we handle S3 arns compared to AWS. For instance
AWS will honor "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::*/test.txt" where Euca will not. The real issue seems to be that 
Euca requires a separate "auths" one for "buckets" and one for "objects", so one "arn" will not address both as it does
with AWS. I am not sure how to handle this as it seems we would need to completely change the way we 
process s3 arns? Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

Unit test : Create an non-eucalyptus user and apply the above policy.

Run the following three commands:
1)  s3cmd -c yourConfig mb s3://test_bucket
2)  s3cmd -c yourConfig put test.txt s3://test_bucket
3)  s3cmd -c yourConfig get -f s3://test_bucket/test.txt

With the fix all three will complete successfully.
Without the fix:
3) s3cmd -c yourConfig get -f s3://test_bucket/test.txt  
will Fail with the following: ERROR: S3 error: 403 (Forbidden): 

Thx Mike

With this change we are now treating an S3 resource ARN with a wildcard bucket/object "*/*' as a wildcard resource "*". So this would match resources other than S3 resources, this is not ideal from a security perspective.

Functionally, I think we now handle S3 resources with ARNs with bucket or bucket/object wildcards but not ARNs with a wildcard bucket and specified object name (assuming this is supported in AWS/S3), e.g. "arn:aws:s3:::*/readme.txt".

[~mmunn1], fix looks good. I think that is right approach for now. I think we'll have to revisit this later for handling partial-object matches (i.e. bucket/objectkey/\*), as can be done in AWS, but for now I think this is the right approach: address the immediate issue which is the '*' as a full wildcard for buckets and objects.
[~mmunn1], I moved the fix to QA to early... sorry about that.

[~mmunn1], after reading [~sjones]'s feedback I see what he's saying. The WildCardResourceName() ERN has a wildcard for the resource type as well, which means it exceeds the scope of just s3_bucket or s3_object. A better solution may be to modify the S3ResourceName in a way the is a wildcard just for the bucket & object.

Making a third return option S3ResourceName.getResourceType() for the wildcard would allow "S3:\*" in the resource type rather than "\*". So rather than using the WildCardResourceName type a safer solution is to modify the S3ResourceName to include wildcards in the right places or create an S3WildcardResourceName to keep the scope specific to the S3 namespace. That's my bad, I should have caught it in the WildcardResourceName earlier.
There are multiple issues with IAM wiidcard use and I will not have a fix for this in 3.4. This will need to be addressed in 4.0

Looks like this use case is supported in S3:
 * http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/s3-arn-format.html

With a fix in place:

{code}
#
# euare-accountcreate sjones
sjones	000099999105
# 
# 
# euare-usercreate --as-account sjones sjones
# 
# 
# euare-useraddkey --as-account sjones sjones
AKIAAV3L5NKK55AG6L3M
wbVYu4fnCBT5jMFoLq9gqqa2dFuWBestHkNOpiSy
# 
# 
# aws configure
AWS Access Key ID [****************QCM2]: AKIAAV3L5NKK55AG6L3M
AWS Secret Access Key [****************IB8n]: 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
Default region name [None]: 
Default output format [None]: 
# 
# 
# aws --endpoint $S3_URL s3 mb s3://sjones-bucket-1/
make_bucket failed: s3://sjones-bucket-1/ A client error () occurred when calling the CreateBucket operation: 

# 
# 
# euare-useruploadpolicy --as-account sjones -u sjones -p s3 -o '{
>   "Statement": [
>     {
>       "Sid": "Stmt1361565586161",
>       "Action": "s3:*",
>       "Effect": "Allow",
>       "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::*"
>     }
>   ]
> }'
# 
# 
# aws --endpoint $S3_URL s3 mb s3://sjones-bucket-1/
make_bucket: s3://sjones-bucket-1/
# 
# 
# vi file.txt # create file with any content for test use
# 
# 
# aws --endpoint $S3_URL s3 cp --acl public-read file.txt s3://sjones-bucket-1/
upload: ./file.txt to s3://sjones-bucket-1/file.txt
# 
# 
# aws --endpoint $S3_URL s3 cp s3://sjones-bucket-1/file.txt s3://sjones-bucket-1/file-copy.txt 
copy: s3://sjones-bucket-1/file.txt to s3://sjones-bucket-1/file-copy.txt
# 
# 
# aws --endpoint $S3_URL s3 cp s3://sjones-bucket-1/file-copy.txt ./
download: s3://sjones-bucket-1/file-copy.txt to ./file-copy.txt
# 
# 
# ll file-copy.txt 
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 5 Oct 29 17:13 file-copy.txt
# 
# 
# aws --endpoint $S3_URL s3 rm s3://sjones-bucket-1/file.txt
delete: s3://sjones-bucket-1/file.txt
# 
# 
# aws --endpoint $S3_URL s3 rm s3://sjones-bucket-1/file-copy.txt
delete: s3://sjones-bucket-1/file-copy.txt
# 
# 
# aws --endpoint $S3_URL s3 rb s3://sjones-bucket-1/
remove_bucket: s3://sjones-bucket-1/
#
#
{code}

test uses AWS CLI (e.g. yum install python-pip; pip install awscli)
